natural problem: What is the units digit of $13^{2003}$?
natural solution: Powers of 13 have the same units digit as the corresponding powers of 3; and $$ 3^1 = 3, \quad 3^2 = 9, \quad 3^3 = 27, \quad 3^4 = 81, \quad\text{and}\quad 3^5 = 243. $$Since the units digit of $3^1$ is the same as the units digit of $3^5$, units digits of powers of 3 cycle through $3, 9, 7,$ and $1$.
Hence the units digit of $3^{2000}$ is $1$, so the units digit of $3^{2003}$ is $\boxed{7}$. The same is true of the units digit of $13^{2003}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 13 ^ 2003"
shows  "n mod 10 = 7"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the units digit of $13^{2003}$? The final Answer is 7
 ### Proof
 Powers of 13 have the same units digit as the corresponding powers of 3; and $$ 3^1 = 3, \quad 3^2 = 9, \quad 3^3 = 27, \quad 3^4 = 81, \quad\text{and}\quad 3^5 = 243. $$Since the units digit of $3^1$ is the same as the units digit of $3^5$, units digits of powers of 3 cycle through $3, 9, 7,$ and $1$.
 Hence the units digit of $3^{2000}$ is $1$, so the units digit of $3^{2003}$ is $\boxed{7}$. The same is true of the units digit of $13^{2003}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 13 ^ 2003"
shows  "n mod 10 = 7"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Find the remainder when $13^{2003}$ is divided by 10. The final answer is $7$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 2003"
shows  "13 ^ n mod 10 = 7"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the units digit of $13^{2003}$? The final Answer is 7
 ### Proof
 Powers of 13 have the same units digit as the corresponding powers of 3; and $$ 3^1 = 3, \quad 3^2 = 9, \quad 3^3 = 27, \quad 3^4 = 81, \quad\text{and}\quad 3^5 = 243. $$Since the units digit of $3^1$ is the same as the units digit of $3^5$, units digits of powers of 3 cycle through $3, 9, 7,$ and $1$.
 Hence the units digit of $3^{2000}$ is $1$, so the units digit of $3^{2003}$ is $\boxed{7}$. The same is true of the units digit of $13^{2003}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 2003"
shows  "13 ^ n mod 10 = 7"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Find the last digit of $13^{2003}$. The final answer is 7.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. f n = (13 ^ n) mod 10"
shows  "f 2003 = 7"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the units digit of $13^{2003}$? The final Answer is 7
 ### Proof
 Powers of 13 have the same units digit as the corresponding powers of 3; and $$ 3^1 = 3, \quad 3^2 = 9, \quad 3^3 = 27, \quad 3^4 = 81, \quad\text{and}\quad 3^5 = 243. $$Since the units digit of $3^1$ is the same as the units digit of $3^5$, units digits of powers of 3 cycle through $3, 9, 7,$ and $1$.
 Hence the units digit of $3^{2000}$ is $1$, so the units digit of $3^{2003}$ is $\boxed{7}$. The same is true of the units digit of $13^{2003}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. f n = (13 ^ n) mod 10"
shows  "f 2003 = 7"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Find the last digit of $13^{2003}$. The final answer is $7$.
